case_name: Proprietors of the West End Hotel v. Corporation of Bangalore

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 28, 1967 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 704 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 28, 1967 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 704 of 1966. B. Datar, for the appellant. R. Somnath Iyer and S. P. Nayar, for respondent No. 1. Rameshwar Nath, for respondent No. 2.

facts.text: High Court of Mysore dismissing the prayer for a declaration of the invalidity of s. 99(2)(b) of the City of Bangalore Municipal Corporation Act, 1949 as amended by the City of Bangalore Municipal Corporation Amendment Act, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of the High Court of Mysore dismissing the prayer for a declaration of the invalidity of s. 99 2  b  of the City of Bangalore Municipal Corporation Act, 1949- hereinafter referred to as the Corporation Act-as amended by the City of Bangalore Municipal Corporation  Amendment  Act, 1964-hereinafter referred to as the 1964 Act.

facts.text: High Court gave limited relief to the appellant in respect of notice No. 4606 dated March 31, 1966 issued by the Assistant Revenue Officer, Corporation of Bangalore, and quashed it to the extent it related to the period anterior to the date of notice.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated March 28, 1967 the High Court gave a limited relief to the appellant in respect of the numberice No. 4606 dated March. 31, 1966 issued by the Assistant Revenue Officer, Corporation of Benglore, to the appellant and quashed it to the extent it related to the period anterior to, the date of numberice.

facts.text: Notice issued to the appellant on March 30, 1966 demanding a sum of Rs. 35,717.20 as tax on vacant land measuring 89,293 sq. yds. at 0.4 of the market value, plus Education Cess, plus Health Cess with effect from April 1, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the powers companyferred upon the Municipal Corporation of Bangalore under the Corporation Act, as amended by the 1964 Act, to levy tax on the basis of estimated market value of lands, a numberice was issued to the appellant on March 30, 1966 demanding a sum of Rs. 35,717.20 as tax on vacant land. It was stated in the numberice that the vacant land, over and above the limit, measuring 89,293 sq. yds. is assessed at 0.4 of the market value, plus Education Cess, plus Health Cess with effect from April 1, 1965.

facts.text: Appellant company are the proprietors of the West End Hotel, Race Course Road, Bangalore.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companypany are the proprietors of the West End Hotel, Race Course Road, Bangalore. The premises of the hotel companyprises a total extent of 19.43 acres or 11,19,168 sq. ft. out of which the building area is 1,05,683 sq. ft.

facts.text: City of Bangalore Municipal Corporation Act, 1949 amended by City of Bangalore Municipal Corporation Amendment Act, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: judgment of the High Court of Mysore dismissing the prayer for a declaration of the invalidity of s. 99 2  b  of the City of Bangalore Municipal Corporation Act, 1949- hereinafter referred to as the Corporation Act-as amended by the City of Bangalore Municipal Corporation  Amendment  Act, 1964-hereinafter referred to as the 1964 Act.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 28, 1967 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 704 of 1966. B. Datar, for the appellant. R. Somnath Iyer and S. P. Nayar, for respondent No. 1. Rameshwar Nath, for respondent No. 2.

The appellant also filed a writ petition under art. 226 of the Constitution challenging s. 99 2  b  of the Corporation Act, as amended by the 1964 Act, as unconstitutional and void and prayed for other consequential reliefs. We may now set out the relevant provisions of the Corpora- tion Act, as amended by the 1964 Act.

The new provision, section 99 2  b  of the Corporation Act, introduced by the amending Act is beyond the legislative competence of the State Legislature. The said provision is violative of the fundamental rights of the petitioners guaranteed under Articles 14 and 19 1  f  of the Constitution.  Note The case of alleged violation of Article 19  1  f , it is conceded, is not available to the petitioner in writ Petition 704 of 1966 which is an incorporated Company.

concepts.interpretation: Court holds the tax on vacant land at 0.4% of market value and classification of excess vacant land not violative as uniform rate, market value related to potential income, and classification reasonable due to land scarcity and public interest.

anchor.surface_text: The said provision is violative of the fundamental rights of the petitioners guaranteed under Articles 14 and 19 1  f  of the Constitution.  Note The case of alleged violation of Article 19  1  f , it is conceded, is not available to the petitioner in writ Petition 704 of 1966 which is an incorporated Company.  The Corporation has omitted to observe the procedure prescribed by section 98 of the Corporation Act, and cannot therefore levy the tax.

concepts.interpretation: Not available to incorporated company petitioner.

arguments.court_reasoning: We are unable to hold that it is a new tax. Tax was being levied before the 1964 Act. The lands were being assessed to property tax even before the 1964 Act, either separately or as part of the building.

arguments.claim: The tax on vacant land is violative of Art. 14 because it is levied at an average rate without any relation to the actual or potential income of the land.

anchor.surface_text: It is companytended that the tax on vacant land is violative of Art. 14 of the Constitution because  i  it is levied at an average rate without any relation to the actual or potential income of the land

arguments.court_reasoning: market value of land always bears a definite relationship to the actual or potential income being derived or derivable from the land and there cannot be any objection to a levy at uniform rate on the market value.

arguments.claim: The manner of determining the market value is discriminatory and vague violating Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: ii  the manner of determining the market value was discriminatory, and  iii  the classification of vacant land and land appurtenant to a building is discriminatory. The learned counsel relied on the decision of this Court in Kunnathat Thathunni Moopil Nair v. The state of Kerala. It was urged by the learned counsel that the expression estimated value and the word area are very vague.

arguments.court_reasoning: We are unable to agree... the Commissioner is directed to look at the lands which are similarly situate, and are similar in nature to the lands being assessed... lands similarly situate and of similar potentiality should be taken as exemplars.

arguments.claim: The classification of vacant land and land appurtenant to a building (up to thrice area vs excess) is discriminatory under Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: It was next companytended that the classification of vacant land is discriminatory. While land appurtenant to a building used as garden and as grounds for the more beneficial enjoyment of such building, number exceeding thrice the area occupied by such building, has been treated as a part of the building and taxed as such, land in excess of thrice the area of a building and other lands number appurtenant to buildings have been classified separately.

arguments.court_reasoning: in cities like Bangalore, where land is scarce, excessive use of land as gardens and grounds is number in the public interest and the legislature can validly tax the excess land on a different and higher basis. Three times the area occupied by a building is number a small area and we are unable to hold that this figure is number reasonable.

arguments.claim: Fixing property tax at 0.4 per cent of market value is itself discriminatory.

anchor.surface_text: The next question that arises is whether fixing property tax at 0.4 per cent is itself discriminatory.

arguments.court_reasoning: If all lands are assessed to the same rate of taxation we are unable to see how there is per se any discrimination... market value of property is one of the indices of the benefit which the owner derives or can derive from it.

arguments.claim: The impugned provisions are not discriminatory under Article 14 as market value relates to potential income and uniform rate is permissible.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to hold that the impugned Act is discrimi- natory. The scheme of the Act is that the market value of the land is first ascertained and then tax at 0.4 per cent is levied.

arguments.claim: The tax is not a new tax requiring section 98 procedure as lands were previously assessed to property tax.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to hold that it is a new tax. Tax was being levied before the 1964 Act. The lands were being assessed to property tax even before the 1964 Act, either separately or as part of the building. We cannot say that this tax is being imposed for the first time within the meaning of s. 98.

arguments.claim: The classification distinguishing appurtenant land up to thrice building area from excess vacant land is reasonable and non-discriminatory.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that in cities like Bangalore, where land is scarce, excessive use of land as gardens and grounds is number in the public interest and the legislature can validly tax the excess land on a different and higher basis.

holdings.text: The case of alleged violation of Article 19(1)(f) is not available to the petitioner which is an incorporated company.

anchor.surface_text: Note The case of alleged violation of Article 19  1  f , it is conceded, is not available to the petitioner in writ Petition 704 of 1966 which is an incorporated Company.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conceded by petitioner that Article 19(1)(f) does not apply to incorporated companies.

holdings.text: The impugned Act is not discriminatory under Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to hold that the impugned Act is discrimi- natory. The scheme of the Act is that the market value of the land is first ascertained and then tax at 0.4 per cent is levied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Market value basis relates to potential income; uniform rate applied to all lands; distinguishes precedents like Moopil Nair where no relation to income.

holdings.text: Market value of land bears definite relationship to actual or potential income; uniform levy at 0.4% on market value not violative of Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: market value of land always bears a definite relationship to the actual or potential income being derived or derivable from the land and there cannot be any objection to a levy at uniform rate on the market value.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Market value inherently reflects potential income derivable from land, justifying uniform rate unlike flat tax unrelated to productivity.

holdings.text: Manner of determining market value by reference to estimated value in the area using similarly situated lands is not discriminatory or vague.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Directs use of standard market value assessment principle: exemplar lands similarly situated and of similar potentiality in defined locality (commercial, residential, etc.).

holdings.text: Fixing property tax at 0.4% of market value is not discriminatory under Article 14.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Uniform rate on market value, an index of benefit/ potential income, permissible; distinguishes cases like Haji K. Kutty based on floor area.

holdings.text: Classification distinguishing appurtenant land (up to thrice building area) from excess vacant land is reasonable and not violative of Article 14.
holdings.reasoning_summary: In land-scarce cities, limiting appurtenant land to thrice building area reasonable to discourage excessive non-revenue use; promotes public interest.

holdings.text: The amendment is not imposition of a new tax requiring procedure under section 98.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to hold that it is a new tax. Tax was being levied before the 1964 Act. The lands were being assessed to property tax even before the 1964 Act, either separately or as part of the building. We cannot say that this tax is being imposed for the first time within the meaning of s. 98.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Property tax on lands existed pre-1964 amendment, assessed separately or with buildings; amendment merely changes basis, not new levy.

precedents.citation: Assistant Commissioner of Urban Land Tax v. The Buckingham Carnatic Co., 1

anchor.surface_text: Assistant Commissioner of Urban Land Tax v. The Buckingham Carnatic Co., 1

precedents.case_name: Assistant Commissioner of Urban Land Tax v. The Buckingham Carnatic Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: the new provision introduced by the amending Act is within the legislative competence of the State Legislature

precedents.citation: Kunnathat Thathunni Moopil Nair v. The state of Kerala 1

anchor.surface_text: Kunnathat Thathunni Moopil Nair v. The state of Kerala 1 . It will be remembered that the charging section in that case was s. 4 of the Travancore-Cochin Land Tax Act, 1955, which read as follows Subject to the provisions of this Act, there shall be charged and levied in respect of all lands in the State, of whatever description and held under whatever tenure, a uniform rate of tax to be called the basic tax.

precedents.case_name: Kunnathat Thathunni Moopil Nair v. State of Kerala
precedents.cited_proposition: tax on land without reference to actual or potential income or productivity is discriminatory under Article 14 as it leads to inequality
precedents.cited_holding: Ordinarily, a tax on land or land revenue is assessed on the actual or the potential productivity of the land sought to be taxed. In other words, the tax has reference to the income actually made, or which could have been made, with due diligence [...] inequality is writ large on the Act and is inherent in the very provisions of the taxing section.

precedents.citation: Kunnathat Thathunni Moopil Nair v. The State of Kerala 1

anchor.surface_text: Kunnathat Thathunni Moopil Nair v. The State of Kerala 1  were quite different. There no attention was paid at all to the income of. the land.

precedents.case_name: Kunnathat Thathunni Moopil Nair v. State of Kerala
precedents.cited_proposition: tax on land without reference to income was discriminatory

precedents.citation: State of Kerala v. Haji K. Kutty 2

anchor.surface_text: State of Kerala v. Haji K. Kutty 2 . There the facts were again quite different. The legislature adopted the floor-area of the building as the basis of tax irrespective of all other consideration.

precedents.case_name: State of Kerala v. Haji K. Kutty
precedents.cited_proposition: using floor-area of building as basis of tax irrespective of other considerations stands on different footing and was discriminatory

outcome.relief_summary: Constitutional challenge to s.99(2)(b) rejected; tax on vacant land upheld as not violative of Art.14; classification reasonable; not a new tax, s.98 procedure not required.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to hold that it is a new tax. Tax was being levied before the 1964 Act. The lands were being assessed to property tax even before the 1964 Act, either separately or as part of the building. We cannot say that this tax is being imposed for the first time within the meaning of s. 98.
